WOzlyltyIkVgFJY_Vxob1Q.text: been here twice. first time was pretty okay, it's something that i would come back for if i dont know what to eat around vegas area.   second time, the beef noodle was very bad, on a scale of 1 to 10, 10 being the most delicious. I give it a 4.   the soup base was way too spicy, and noodle was very mushy.   I kindly told the store owner/ server that last time i came, the noodle didn't taste like this and was wondering what happened, I was just expecting a simple sorry, and we will make it better, or something like i can try to make it taste better right now. but no, he was like OH you came in at a very busy time, and we remake the soup and it's SUPPOSED TO TASTE A LITTLE DIFFERENT!   i swear the soup was too spicy for sake. i didn't even eat 1/5 of it. and Ima big time eat and I LOVE beef stew noodle, and it was that bad that I couldnt eat it.   the rest of the food were okay, but just the beef noodle was gross.  I'd like to just inform people that don't go in if they look busy, because the soup will just be too spicy, and it's supposed to be like that!   service was okay, a little slow during busy hours, but they're pretty nice, except for the part when they tried to make excuses for that noodle.

UAOCnodrZiahJDJfxXbeOg.text: Best Chinese food in Las Vegas. We had wonton noodle soup with extra veggies, scallion pancakes, and pork dumplings. Split between two people we could not eat it all. Also it was so cheap! Fast service and friendly.

EH4H38NkGtsjuNAbEwJUpg.text: So it is only fitting that my 100th review would involve pretty much my favorite meal of all time.  Beef noodle soup was a common meal for me growing up so I've always sought after that grandmas recipe type that you could have anytime even if the weather was hot outside. I have to say, Noodle Pot is certainly high on my list for a solid bowl of Beef Noodle Soup. I've tried a couple other things in their menu including the Beef Roll and Spicy Chile Wontons, both of which are alright, but my go to here is always their Beef Noodle Soup. Ask for it to be made spicy even though it's not. It's just that if you don't, the broth comes out really bland. Great service and fast. Meal on the table in less than 5 minutes wait time. With it being right next to Diamond Bakery, it's a cant miss. I love to swing next door and grab some Portuguese Egg Custards.

2SCA4YgdSrj9xKPanlt_Hw.text: Great beef and tendon noodle soup! The beef is cooked perfectly and the soup is very tasty. The most important thing of a bowl of noodle soup is the noodle itself, and their noodles have great texture. Definitely would come back again!

LhcnR5TwWhfxh6wFKuMHuQ.text: Such amazing food! The beef roll was so flavorful! Beef tendon noodles were awesome! So were the pork and chicken dumplings! Ordered a lot of food but it was all so good.... I. Didn't. Regret. A. Thing.

JJdOFL7JsnW-tygeEnjTpw.text: Wow! This spot is delicious. It's not the most attractive place, but the food is phenomenal. The beef rolls were amazing and huge - thin pancakes wrapped around an egg omlette stuffed with fresh green veggies and sliced beef (the sliced beef is really amazing here, I recommend trying the cold preparation of it). The soups are great, I particularly loved the beef stew with dumpling - they do a great job of cooking the beef so that it melts in your mouth and the spice isn't their just for spice's sake. The scallion pancakes are some of the best I've had. Just a great experience.

GGzb-S2GV0Sf8LHPGRXMEw.text: Looking for some Northern style noodles.  You've found it!  One of many but this one's convenience in the 99 Ranch shopping mall makes it an easy choice since you probably can get some grocery beforehand...then boba afterwards.  (though there are some much better boba places elsewhere).  The place is small and often packed.  So don't expect too much.  But at least the food is cheap and tasty.

nPQ6-AUGmhid-lRR4Elg4A.text: Great option for quick, cheap and delicious food.   We arrived around 11AM and got a table fairly quickly. The place was packed by 11:45AM. There was only one server when we were there so service was slightly slower than I preferred, but she was very sweet and helpful.   We ordered a few noodle dishes, napa and pork dumplings, spicy wontons, scallion pancakes, beef rolls, fried pork chop, and pickled cucumbers. The dumplings, scallion pancakes, beef rolls, and pickled cucumbers are a must! The fried pork chop was very tasty as well, super tender and fatty. The spicy wontons were decent, could've used a little more flavor. The jajang noodles were a little overwhelming so we could've done without, but the noodles with tomato sauce were great.   Overall, we really enjoyed eating here and would definitely keep this in mind for our next visit to Vegas.

LfBsfqsu1GxXzfnZhSUjGA.text: We are from out of town and wanted noodles for breakfast. What a great find! The noodles were fresh and slurpy. My son ordered the minced pork and rice and it was delicious. Great portions. Would definitely return if we are in the area!

WQpOeYlyA3f0PqX1_cfExw.text: For us this place seemed to lack what we expected. We found that 2 of the dishes we ordered came in a chili oil sauce....this was found in the pickled cucumbers and dry noodle dish; it made both dishes quite oily. From our experience with pickled cucumbers it's usually only in a sesame and garlic sauce. The noodles were also quite oily and lacked any depth in taste; I added a little of the dumpling sauce to add a little saltiness to the dish and in my opinion that helped improve the taste. The beef roll was a lot bigger than we expected, but we were not used to the egg layer or the tendons in the beef which made it difficult to chew. The pork and chive dumplings was the only dish we enjoyed. Maybe their noodle soups would have been a better option but we probably won't be coming back because the dishes we ordered are generally what we like at Taiwanese restaurants.

H5VEOxvOYu2rh8WsaBEdcg.text: Noodle Pot is famous for their beef noodle soup and it does NOT dissapoint!  The broth is so savory, flavorful, and frangrant, the noodles and bokchoy are plentiful...  Can it get any better?  I don't think so! The chunks of beef and tendon are cooked tender and the portions are very generous.  It's money well spent!  Fried Pork chop?  Nothing fancy but delicious nonetheless.  It's lightly fried and had the perfect chinese marinades going on.  Loved it.  Beef rolls?  Amazing too.  The crepes were egg-y and light and the sweet hoisin sauce, tender beef, and crispy cucumbers was perfect-o.  Would I come back here?  HECK YA!

I don't know how good the food is but the restaurant is suppose to close at midnight and we were there at 11:36pm and they told us they are closed, and the sign still says "open".  If they want to close at 11:30 then why don't they just say they close at 11:30 instead of midnight.   I would never come back to try the food.

QjX0NgQt52KNclpL-IleJg.text: Was craving nul ro mein since it was a cold, rainy weekend in Vegas. I also wanted to get away from the strip for a little bit so ventured over to the "china town" all along Spring Mountain. This place got great reviews for their nul ro mein and dumplings so I picked this place.   It's a smaller but cozy mom and pop with friendly servers. Although the hot tea was served in plastic water cups, it was pretty tasty and went perfectly with the meal. Unfortunately, they ran out of the wide noodles for the nul ro mein so I just went for the regular beef noodle soup sinced I didn't want the spice. The broth was light and slightly tangy from the pickled cucumbers. Even though I didn't have the thick noodles, the thin noodles were pretty good. They definitely tasted home made and a slight chew to them which I love. The beef was thinly sliced and somewhat rubbery/chewy - I was definitely not a fan.  Overall, I've had better bowls of noodle soup elsewhere and left slightly disappointed. Then again, I didn't have the spicy beef noodle soup or have the wide noodle either.

k0BK5H09wOwC3XH6NKi3mw.text: I am going to keep this review simple and short. Food is average...more on the greasy side. Service is HORRIBLE. As I walked out I said "the service is horrible here" and a customer waiting for a table said I can tell.

WqxpBxqNNEHTFOtTK1saUQ.text: This was a pleasant surprise - authentic Taiwanese noodle house in Vegas.  I had the wonton noodle, which was good.  Others in my party had the beef noodle, apparently their signature dish, and said it was Taiwan-quality good.    Well worth the short cab ride if you have a group to split the bill.  You may even come out ahead on cost, vs. eating on The Strip.  Just remember that in Vegas, the maximum a cab takes is 5 people.We had to take two cabs for our party of six, so the financials did not work out as well.

XfKvi5vr2r4Pvfuex26N8w.text: This was one of the worst experience's I've had! Customer service was horrible, since I cannot leave the rating zero, I am forced to give them a one, but believe me I wouldn't go back if it was free!    Let me explain, we walked in for a hot bowl of noodles, and the place had maybe 8 tables of people.  We were shown a table and sat down, and that was it, no one came over to take our order, we were there maybe 10 minutes when a bus load of people came flooding through the doors and scrambling for free tables, they were placing orders and their food came flying out, one after another, it was horrific.  I finally got someones attention and they took our order.    Finally, our food came out but they kept pushing us around, first by asking that we move to a single table, we had been seated by them at a table for four, so we complied, then when my husband made his way to the counter to pay, I was still slurping my noodles, they showed people to sit at our table, I wasn't even done eating and they were pushing us out to make room for 'THE BUS' people.  I have never felt so unwanted, I was a paying customer too!  I wanted to sit and enjoy my meal, and yet I was rushed, pushed out of my seat!  I couldn't take it any more, I was livid, so I walked out, disgusted with the whole experience, and I will not go back!

7bJ8Kz24aDMRDIM9WJ1e7w.text: After I finally persuaded Earl to come here for a late lunch, we got to visit Noodle Pot.  Earl hesitated to come here because we had a 7 course chef tasting dinner planned at 6pm, and it is already 2pm.    When we arrived, we were promptly greeted by the staff and was seated.  Choice between hot tea and water was offered, we opted for hot tea.  We ordered the two most talked about items on Yelp.  While we were waiting, Earl was intrigued by the Taiwanese variety show that was playing on the TV.  I, on the other hand, was intrigued with the big freezer that located inside the dining area, packed with frozen meat and trays of handmade wontons.   Onto the food:  -Beef and Tendon Noodle Soup:  We asked for extra bowls so we can share this.  This is a huge bowl of spicy flavorful broth with super tender chunks of beef and tendons.  There were also baby bok choy and pickled veggie in this bowl of goodness.    -Beef roll: tender slices of beef, egg and tons and tons of cilantro, with hoisin sauce, rolled up with a mu shu like wrapper.  There were two rolls, sliced in three sections, that came in an order.  We each had a section and took home the rest because we want to save room for dinner.  We had it for breakfast this morning and it was still delicious.  Service was awesome. Food we had was awesome. We will be coming back!

srQYGPHBEtb_nhavFqQ01A.text: Everything we had was excellent. Beef and tendon noodle, the pig ear salad, pig feet stew, shrimp and chive dumplings and nice service for an Asian place. Would definitely return!

8KcxI7oMZl-FAqIrBrh2QA.text: I have a weakness and it is NOODLES!  Even the scorching hot sun could not keep me away from a hot bowl of noodle soup.  Open late and tucked into the Chinatown plaza, I knew I had to go take a visit.  AMBIENCE: This is a great place if Pho Kim Long down the way is too full.  This is not a fancy shmancy restaurant, but it's a great spot to get a quick fill of your noodle cravings and go.  They also seem to store their meats in the fridge in the dining area, which is a little strange, but nonetheless entertaining to see all the different kinds of meat they have stocked in there when they go to pull something out.  FOOD QUALITY: The noodle soup was delicious!!! I got the Wonton noodles and the broth was just perfect!  The wonton was tender and tasty and the noodles were melt in your mouth yummy!  The portion was also generous enough to satisfy my tummy.  Price was cheap too - I don't believe any of the noodles came out to be more than $8.    OVERALL: The noodles were so yummy, I would definitely put this place on the list to come back to for my next Vegas visit.  Plus, I now have another alternative if Pho Kim Long's line ever gets too long.

xue0_U49BcHO0YaiHA9wrw.text: Want to try some quality beef soup noodles?  A few simple choices an you're there:   1.  Beef, beef tendon, or a combination of both. 2.  Thin or thick (hand cut ribbons) noodles. 3.  Mild or spicy soup.  The hardest thing is finding the place.    Deconstructed:  Very well seasoned, deep beefy soup base with the wafting aroma of star anise, hint of ginger, and dried citrus peels.  Great noodles with just the right amount of chew.  Clean, tender, gelatinous tendons (sounds disgusting but "a rose by any other name...").  The only catch, the beef is sometimes over braised.  Tender, but dry.  Very common, I'd guess it's authentic by default.  Beef stew soup $8. Beef tendon soup $9.  Combo at $8.50  A simple meal doled out in a non descript restaurant with "classic" service (you got your food right?)  It is what it is and that's not bad at all.

ZKT5jnkqonHMCX_WygqQkw.text: If you're in Vegas and looking for a bomb meal before you go out and get drunk off your ass, or you're looking for a hangover cure the next day, then this is the spot!  Hands down best beef noodles in Vegas, probably better than most beef noodles in the 626/909 area too. For a Taiwanese joint, this place is as authentic as it gets. The noodles are handmade and the perfect size. You don't find beef noodles with texture this good just anywhere. The broth is a little spicy (legit Taiwanese-style), so try the mild if you're scared of spicy shits.   The shrimp dumplings and wontons in chili sauce are delicious as well. Really reminds me of the ones you get in a Taiwanese night market. If you're down to try something new, I would also recommend the beef rolls.  I go here at least once every time I'm in Vegas and I'm in town quite often.

LhiruPw5x26mvVo3-9v07w.text: Our first time at noodle pot...waitress has no personality. Felt really awkward eating there since we were not Chinese or Korean. Worst service ever and never going there again. Food is not as good as it is rated. The egg was over cooked and hard...yuck!

oA4szCmbh7PbU2YXTJtS4g.text: Hello?! Yummy hot Taiwanese noodle soup?! Yes please! I had the soy sauce seaweed and it was so good. The texture wasn't as fresh or crunchy but it was tender and tasty. I had the spicy beef and tendon noodle soup, and the noodles were not the thin rice noodles. It was hot and filling and the ramen style noodles paired with the spicy rich flavor of the broth and soft tendons was just the right amount of everything. 2 bowls and the appetizer was just under $25 so this place is now one of my top fave noodle houses.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Pot - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soooo frackin good.

mw6FwGBPko3Pw3lgTlypgw.text: beef noodle soup and the pork/veggie dumplings are just what the doctor ordered. this 1-2 punch of savory goodness is gonna make your face royal-flushed when the sweet sweet msg kicks in. almost missed my flight out of vegas cuz of this meal but it was still worf it. l'oreal.   the wifi password to this place is 12345678. is this real life?

4uJ-udWuIoBmA2ZOIB-z4A.text: I frequent this place about once a week to get my fill on Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup. It's the best I've ever had, though I am no "expert" on authentic taste. However, my friends who are much more in tune with the traditional flavor say that it is *very* good. This is primarily the dish I stick with, as it is their primary specialty, I believe.  Their beef, as compared to most places I've had in California, is tender, quality meat. A&J, a semi-chain, has these comparatively cheap pieces of beef with fat layered into it. I know which I prefer. The soup is very good, as are the noodles, and at 8 dollars a dish, you really can't go wrong as the meal is also very filling.  I've also enjoyed the beef rolls here - essentially sliced beef with some hoisin style sauce and a lot of cilantro-type herbs and egg wrapped into a thin pancake. They're really tasty as well.  Additionally, I do find that the owners and workers here are better than most hole-in-the-wall Taiwanese restaurants. Sometimes I could simply not stand the way I was treated at places like A&J.  A couple tips. CASH ONLY, and they often close before the listed closing time if they are not busy at all. Like potentially two hours early, so either call or be prepared to go early!

pBZw2O3o9GQVPv_d7fVgGA.text: Whenever my Chinese in-laws are visiting from Hong Kong and we go to Chinese restaurants, I am always on the edge of my seat eagerly  awaiting for their opinion (and approval).  I had been here once before and really like it so I added it to the list of places to take them.  Well, I am proud to say that my taste buds were on point because they were big fans of Noodle Pot.    Most of the noodle restaurants in Chinatown are Cantonese style, but Noodle Pot is  traditional Taiwanese style. On both occasions, my husband and I shared the big bowl of the Beef and tendon stew noodle soup.  It is supposed to be spicy, but we also have to add more to appease our spice needs.  The noodles are made from scratch and hand pulled every morning. The beef and tendons are oh so tender, and the broth is bursting with flavor.    I highly recommend ordering the Beef Roll to accompany the noodle soup. The flavor combinations of the egg wrap, the cilantro, thin sliced beef, and hoisin sauce is perfection.  There are also cold dishes (pig ear, marinated cucumbers, seaweed, eggs, peanuts, etc) at the counter to accompany your noodles if you prefer.  In addition, they serve an assortment of dumplings which I have yet to try.   I am also a big fan of the rice dishes.  I ordered a crispy chicken plate for the kids and they loved it.  The steamed rice comes with some minced beef on top and some pickled vegetables on the side. But, the crispy chicken is the True star.   The restaurant is a True hole in the wall. (Our table was next to the freezer).  It may be difficult to find if you can't read Chinese. The Chinese Characters dominate the store front sign but be on the lookout for the tiny square of english words "Noodle Pot" in the corner.  The service is quick and friendly, and the flat screen TV is on a Chinese channel.  There are only a few tables inside and it is CASH ONLY, but it is a True GEM to Chinatown.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Pot - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The beef roll with egg wrap and tons of cilantro.

gt7ioRxZ_FlxtoNYdUnYOg.text: Last time I'm ever gonna eat here . I found a piece of hair in my food confronted them about nicely and they didn't bother to do anything about it. My family's  food was cold and the service was very disappointing.

FaAXse3oZRfOaTkvDB1eBg.text: I ordered the beef tendon in noodle soup.  Absolutely delicious.  I would come back every time I go to Vegas.

He11qKS_ZcrX2ncqhPzTHg.text: Hey, not bad at all. The beef noodle soup is soulful and delicious.  Cash Only. No frills.

zsAt3grfLHEMv1mxbG3x2A.text: (+)(+)(+) authentic (-) meat (beef noodle soup) could use some more work  I am from Taiwan. This tastes like home. Albeit this isn't a quality that I would wait in line for if I were in Taiwan, but here in the States, it doesn't get more real than this.  Beef noodle soup - meh, good broth and noodles, mediocre on the meat Veggies in garlic - good, tastes like any other asian sauteed veggie dish Spicy wonton - good, could be more spicy? Pork ears - amazing, it's so hard to find real pork ears... The ears here were not store bought, not excessively fatty, had cartilage in every piece, with good sauce. What else can I say? The ears tasted like they ought, which in America is actually high praise. Green bean soup - amazing. Again, not special, just authentic. Tastes just like how my grandma makes hers. Makes me miss home...  In summary, nothing special. Tastes like a mom and pop shop in any alley of Taipei Taiwan. But that's the crazy thing, tastes just like it does in Taiwan, not adulterated with western influences. Nothing against good American food, but sometimes I just appreciate real Chinese food too.

WSr08RD3Vz4Aais-qQmWpA.text: We ordered the beef spicy noodle soup and wonton in chili sauce. The beef noodle soup was good, but a bit pricey at $9.50 for a small bowl. The wonton is very disappointing. There is  barely any fillings and the chili sauce was bland. I'll probably be back to try other noodle soups.

tN3LE6GpOvRGHppawGtkng.text: I had to lower a star this time around. Want to know why? Because the day before yesterday I ordered the salty duck noodle soup and It was real good. Really good flavor, the meat was tough and with good flavor. But the one complaint that I had with the soup is a very serious one. The meat of the duck soup composed of the neck bone of the duck, and I couldn't enjoy eating it because I constantly had to spit them out and on top of that it was more bone/cartridge than meat.     But thats not my biggest concern is that those small neck bone pieces if not careful are a shocking hazard. I ignorantly shared half of the soup with my elderly mother and by some act of God none of those small neck bones feel into the soup when she was slurping it down. She could of shocked. To give you an image of how small and thick they were imagine it half the size of a small pebble stone. Or a piece of rice crispy cereal. I don't know if there duck soup always is composed of that part of the duck but if they continue to use just that part they will end up with a lawsuit by one of their customers.

nuhq3qSYFw6Ul9gFftEHVg.text: Perfect place for a bowl of satisfying noodle soup. Haven't been to Chinatown Plaza in ages. I'm glad we stopped by and had dinner here. Friends ordered the famous beef noodle soup while I opted for vegetarian noodles. All enjoyed our dinners.

UrCi1iq9SBWky0LM-FvDAA.text: Our family hasn't been to Noodle Pot for four months, because Spring has kept the kids in school. We needed to get out of the one hundred plus degree temperatures last night and so we drove across town to Noodle Pot on Spring Mountain. The weather was 95 degrees during the eleven o'clock news - The heat was so hot. My wife was so pleased that we stopped at Noodle Pot. She loved the ingredients, vegetables. My kids were so happy with his dumplings, meatballs, noodles. The Noodle Pot was busy. We all agree. The Noodle Pot is absolutely fabulous.

a87ZPVJqhmSWc05JR70LIg.text: The beef noodle soup was decent especially for $8.99. Good for a late night dinner or snack. Had the triple delight which was cucumber, tofu and sea weed. It was more like 2.5 stars. Service was good.

Qx3UcL2ZwWeaG67785LZlw.text: If I was only rating based on the  beef noodle stew (which comes in both normal and spicy variety), I would have definitely given this place 5 stars. Only reason I brought it down to four was because the cold dishes we ordered on the side were atrocious. It was so evidently clear that they sat in the fridge for ages that I preferred to leave them untouched.   The cold dishes came out all stuck together and packed together like an ice cube. It actually took the use of a fork to break it apart because chopsticks were too flimsy for the job. Buuuuuut, the beef noodle stew...  Ahhh the beef noodle stew is exquisite. The amount of spices and herbs they use make this extremely tasty. Get the spicy variety as you will not regret it. Huge, bold flavor packed into one bowl, if you are craving beef noodle stew this is the place to go. The store doesn't have a sign outside so look for a place with a Pig as it's mascot (pig from the story Journey to the West).

wMpluN5ITI9qedbjyRlo5A.text: I am always in search of a restaurant that serves really good beef noodle soups.  So I was excited to see the interior of this restaurant being put together a few months ago.  I finally came here with another Yelper for dinner and to give their food a try. The restaurant was not busy at all (I was the only in there while I waited for my friend), so service was quick when we placed our order.  I ordered the Beef Noodle with wide noodles $7.99.  The flavor was good,the noodles were chewy the way I like it, but the beef could have been braised longer.  I think China Mama and even Ay-Chung Noodle has better Beef Noodle Soup, so I will likely try something else here in the future.  My friend tried the Babo Mian, which he said was good.  $6.99  We also ordered an appetizer that was on one of the papers taped to the wall. The chicken was good, just a little pricey for the portion.  Overall, I thought the restaurant was decent.  The food was adequate. Price was alright.   WiFi is free, but there is no place to plug in your laptop.  Decor: 3/5  Nothing special.  Just a fast food restaurant kind of furniture and decorations. Food: 3/5  Okay, but definitely room for improvement. Service: 4/5  Efficient. Location:  4/5  In China Town.  Close enough for the tourists staying on the Strip, and locals wanting to eat at a restaurant on Spring Mtn.  Cash only, which my friend said was the reason why he didn't dine here sooner, as he didn't have cash when he initially came here.  I know it is a business decision to process credit cards payments, but it seems that it is a small business expense to cover to not lose potential businesses from those intending to pay with debit/credit cards.

6J14zo2NcKB8ooLX0BXvtw.text: Dropped in here to try the won tons and beef roll.  Service was fast and friendly, food was good.  We ordered hot green tea and it was served piping hot in plastic cups, wtf?! Is that even safe?  The Won Tons in Red Chili sauce are awesome. They are topped with fresh cilantro, perfect with the acid from the vinegar sauce.  The beef roll was interesting, it's very sweet... like dessert sweet. The beef is tender and the fresh herbs and egg inside give it a light fluffy texture which I loved, but the sauce was too sweet or there was just too much of it for my taste.  I'm keeping this place bookmarked and will come back to try the dumplings and soup noodles, but won't make the mistake of ordering hot tea here again.

V0PAJHAy42DRXYt4-Pm15w.text: Asked for fried pork rice, the boiled egg came with few pieces of eggshells, the rice was not hot enough, my mom asked for their beef noodles, the soup was too salty. In addiction, the attitude of one of their staff was terrible.

jgqSKLoFHaFED45yOgQZmA.text: This is the worse beef noodle soup I ever had, absolutely disgusting, beef soup smells like pork... really make me sick... never wanna come back again

gi26xavfGPdd_Zs2TgmUAg.text: I got the roasted beef noodle soup. The soup was spicy and savory, and there were generous chunks of beef and vegetables. The flavor is quite good; my only complaint is that the noodles are just plain ones, rather than hand-pulled noodles that are chewier and tastier.  3.5 stars

QnvFDs18F6lmI1LZR0e9og.text: I keep hearing about amazing beef noodle soup from fellow yelpers. So decided before heatwave today get me nice bowl of noodle soup. I was NOT at all disappointed. I did get the spicy beef and tendon noodle soup. I enjoy spicy food! I know we all have our own levels of heat but felt spicy was just right not over the top but still feel the kick. The amount of beef and tendon took me surprise with generous portions. I am fan of Pho. I get tendon in my Pho never get enough one piece or two if lucky. Here at Noodle Pot get bang for your buck. The broth was so heavenly no need add nothing else plus had small bok choy pieces in too. The noodles was great! I thinking be more like Pho much thicker noodle close too udon but thiner. I felt made the soup even more hearty with the bigger noodles. Yummy. I also ordered beef roll just cause first trip wanted try as much as I can. Another great dish on the menu. It heavy for starter just so you know. It something that never had before maybe because of the whole restaurant style. It looks more like crepe roll up with thinly sliced of tongue (I think) and lot of other good stuff lot of herbs/greens. You get two nice big rolls pre order. I would take beef roll over any spring roll.   The service say can be hit or miss depending on busy. I happen too during the lunch rush so kind of happy found spot. They only have one server/cashier and she does everything. Although too be honest the cook brought out my noodle soup since it was busy. It came too getting the bill if busy best bet just go right up too the cashier. If had anything pick at was since busy waited long time for bill. Two other tables that they just went right up too pay since taking little bit. Overall service was still very good.   The restaurant is pretty small so timing is everything. I do believe they do take out orders. Parking more then ample being located in Chinatown. If fan of noodles Noodle Pot is some place that need too check out. I know will be back. =))

-0tlFL_dE_Cpm9oZRJG-0Q.text: Great food and friendly staff! The beef noodle soup is really good. Recommended if you want Taiwanese food in the area.

GhzoIxJSfoBxrB4GdfZWKA.text: Beef noodle soup was alright; I had better, but the fried chicken on rice was pretty bad.  I was expecting the typical five spice Taiwanese fried chicken but it was smoked chicken?? Wth? It tasted like smoked ham but with chicken if that makes any sense.  Just weird and off. Definitely disappointing and will not come back.

4rMboOoY6RMQZmJE2V1tsw.text: I thought it was really funny that for parties of 6 or more, there is a mandatory 15% gratuity .. People in Chinatown must normally tip less than 15% ..   CASH ONLY  Prices were pretty fair !!! I ordered the zha jiang mian, and it was slightly different than what I'm used to seeing. It looked like minced pork on noodles here instead of the standard black bean stuff with cucumbers. While it was pretty good, it was not what I was expecting .. Also I think the egg was too salty.   The beef wraps were super good !!!! I highly recommend A+!!! But there is lots of cilantro in it for people who do not like cilantro! Also the pig ear and the marinated cucumbers were good.   Solid place and not super expensive !!

GKMuwEDqVNGohAqD_xcuqA.text: I read a review that someone found a bug in their food. I would've eaten that shit! Ok not really but this place is damn good. The beef noodle broth is so warming and deep in flavor, touches you in all the good spots. I'm not sure if the noodles are made in house, they didn't taste like made to order, but definitely super fresh. Beef rolls were solid too. Yum yum.

UiUyhLauFb8DoB_Siw6xqw.text: The best dish here is the beef roll, very tasty. Noodle is so so in my opinion, the noodle is fresh but i dont like their soup base.

i1cZxSN6cQLXQkU6n_D0dA.text: On our last morning in Vegas, we wanted an Asian breakfast.  We ended up at Noodle Pot because there was no wait.  The restaurant was jam packed though with Asians enjoying their noodles and dumplings.  We ordered their pork chop noodle, with what reminded me of Taiwanese style breaded fried pork chop on the side, beef and tendon noodle, and pork and napa dumplings. The dumplings were very mediocre and the dipping sauce looked like it had dried oregano floating on top.  The beef and tendon soup felt like it was pho, with sliced onions, cilantro, and bean sprouts.  Everything was tasty enough and we were very grateful to get our noodle fix taken care of, but it wasn't the best I've ever had.

bZG1FpJBcg8poFME30pd_Q.text: My girl and I were out and about and stumbled upon Noodle Pot. Right on the entrance door is a Recognition Award noting that it's ranked 13th as the Best Chinese Food in America by a A Bite of America for 2018. Wowie Wow WOW WOWZERS! 13th?!?! That's it we were sold! We had to try it out!   I mean 13th in all of America?!?! If my calculations are correct there's gotta be at least 102 Chinese food places in the United States right? Two for each state and a 3 in Missouri and Alabama? Right? Cuz those Southerners love them some Chinese Food.  Anyways we walked in and the place was moderately packed. It was an early Friday night though. The inside is isn't too large and the food is apparently Taiwanese (Taiwan - the non-communist country). There are a few photos on the wall with numbers that correspond to numbers on the menu. The menu itself offered a good variety.  We wanted a rice dish and a noodle dish along with a couple of side dishes. Here's what we ordered and what we thought.  #12 Salty Duck Soup w/Noodle: The duck was delicious. Tender and portions were good. The noodle lacked flavor and didn't really add anything to the overall dish flavor-wise. It's like when you order a burger and get fries on the side, but the fries are the standard ones and not seasoned or extraordinary. So in this case the noodles were more like filler. I would say order the duck by itself and skip the noodles.  #29 Fried Pork Chop w/Rice: The pork chop was tasty and just the right amount of saltiness. The dish came with rice, a soy sauced hardboiled egg, sweet sausage, bean sprouts, spongy tofu thing, and pickled veggies. The serving size was large and the total dish was good and worth ordering.  #24 Wonton in Red Chili Sauce: This dish wasn't all that great. The chili sauce could've been spicier and the wontons were a bit bland. I've had better. I'd skip this order next time.  #26 Scallions Pancake: This is a pretty traditional dish that both of us enjoy. It's hard to screw up since it's so straightforward like sunny side eggs. We liked it since the pancakes were crispy but not stale or hard. I'd order this again.  The entire meal with what we ordered came out to be under $35 before tip. We both thought the food was okay. Can't say we're fans or we'd go out of our way to eat here again. Maybe if we're in the area and didn't want any of the other bountiful options available in Chinatown we'd drop in again. 3 stars and worth a visit if you've never been, but maybe not worth a second visit.

Photo of Noodle Pot - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried pork chop w/rice. Worth the money. Tasty.

X-a0_7npQIzfEqEvxxdV4Q.text: The service was fast and friendly....and the food is amazing! We got the beef noodle soup. Mine had tendon, which was super tender. We also got the beef roll. I've never had it before but it was good. The soup though was the best! Definitely a must-try!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Pot - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef roll, beef noodle soup, and seaweed, tofu, and pickle appetizer.

xydXLM4Bt6sAWi0Aia1L5A.text: Very much an old school Chinese place--slightly sticky tables jammed together to maximize occupancy in a small space, giving barely enough room to navigate through.  Thankfully it is also old school in terms of cooking ability--homemade dumplings and soup were both good. I'd say neither were quite the best I've had in the US, but both were possibly the best versions I've had in Vegas.  Note that they list a $20 minimum for credit/debit, which is a real pain if you're dining alone. Hence the two items, which on the plus side did give me leftovers.

8G8Wq0cLqYqvGt76in64hQ.text: My first time here and I think I found my go-to noodle spot in the sin city! This place is fairly small but packed full of tables, noodle-lovers and flavors. We ordered 3 items to share family-style among 3 of us. Everything was so tasty that made me think twice about sharing after the first bite! The spiciness was spot on. The broth is so complex with chewy and cooked-to-perfection noodles. More people kept coming in as soon as a table left. We barely heard anything else but the sound of slurping and Chinese, which even further proved that this spot is legit! Thinking that this can't get any better, the bill came out around 30 bucks and I'm officially obsessed. Wish we had more room to stuff our face with more of their delicious noodles. We will definitely come back soon!

ngdh507PPzIKspVF7s8ygA.text: I was visiting Vegas from Los Angeles and had a craving for beef noodle soup. This place did not disappoint. Some of the best beef noodle I've had in years. I am going to make it a point to stop by this place every time I'm back in Vegas.

5s3QMf3lyTLUoL0PQ24efg.text: The best noodles in Vegas in my opinion! Noodle Pot is my new go to noodle restaurant in Las Vegas if I want a fast and inexpensive meals!  This is my 2nd times here and I even like them more than last time. The noodle is so tasty. It maybe not as good as Taiwan or Hong Kong. But please remember, this is Las Vegas. This is almost as good as you can get! I have the Old Beijing style Zajiang noodle with pork this time. It is the best I ever had. It is so delicious! I guess I can eat it every day! Lol!  The parking is easy. Noodle Pot is in the shopping mall together with Ranch 99 Market and a lot of other restaurant. It is not easy if you want to park in front of the restaurant. But it should be no problem if you can park close the the middle of the parking log.

yj7vxiiV7c5ldKC86m5x0Q.text: As others have mentioned, the food is quite good and the prices are very reasonable given how big the portions are.  Go for the soup noodles.  Parking is free and plentiful in the huge lot for this shopping center.  It's about 1 mile away from the strip so don't try to walk here unless it's not very hot outside.  It's worth checking out this restaurant not only for its good soup noodles but also because of the shopping center it is in.  There are lots of other great asian places here so it's worth the trip here from your hotel.  It certainly will be the best priced food you will find in Las Vegas!

zIMyh_e1FSQOBJLDBNdtlA.text: Wow! What an awesome discovery. This restaurant reminded me of my time back in Taipei.  Their beef and tendon spicy soup is great. It's a must when you go to this restaurant. You sit and within minutes your big bowl of soup comes out very quick.  Don't be scared of the word spicy, because it's not at all spicy. It's just right even for me who can't handle spicy food.  Their garlic and veggies are also great. Freshly made!   The only reason why I deducted a star is because my his place is tiny. It can get super crowded and when you get a seat, you are all cramped and hardly able to move and eat.   Also, when you pay with a card, you have to pay in front because you need to sign from their iPad.  Other than that, this place is a must!

htv7UZly8PJjwReJlXCyTA.text: Spicy beef noodles soup with beef roll took away my morning hangover cloud! Very friendly crowd, food is authentic and very good!

B5bkHxFr8VPFaHzp44RZYg.text: If I live in Vegas, I am pretty sure Noodle Pot would be one of my routine restaurants to frequent.  Not that it gets cold too often in Vegas (or at least I don't think), but especially those cold winter nights, I'd probably go like 2-3 times a week.  That's how great their spicy beef and tendon noodle soup is to me.  I've had a great # of bowls of noodle soup...and their is really really good.  Thick-and-a-bit-chewy noodles, flavorful soup with a kick, cooked perfected tender beef tendon and large chunks of beef with the right mix of fat vs. lean.... oh and some veggies.  Anyways, I was really pleasantly surprised by the noodle soup.  We also ordered the beef roll and dumplings.  Beef roll has a bit of sweet taste (preference thing) which I didn't like.  But if you like a bit of sweetness in your food, you'll probably love it.  The dumplings were A-OK.  This is one of those hole in the wall, no frill type restaurants.  So I am a fan and would come back again for their beef noodle soup for sure the next time I am in town.

tX_Zoej-2mGxwr-74sghEw.text: Loved this place. I wish it is located in Phoenix. We were in Vegas for the weekend and went there twice for lunch. Tried different things both time. The homemade noodles are amazing.  If and when we visit again we will try.

Z89TI7RYCSP3SnXnFn0pmg.text: I remember coming here when it first opened 1-2 times and was not that impressed with the food. I also recalled hearing the microwave going off more than anything else before the food came out which made me avoid this place for the longest time.   Recently, one of my friend's friend had came into town and had loved coming here. We all came here for dinner one night before going to play pool and my opinion had been changed. Being one who loves food and eats mostly everything (there are a few exceptions...), I had to get the "Stewed Beef & Tendon w/ Noodle in Spicy Beef Soup". At $11.50 (as of mid 2018), the price seems to have jumped up quite a bit since opening.   Luckily, the last two visits, I haven't heard the microwave go off. Ahaha ! The soup is really flavorful and the noodles are good ! Holds the flavor of the soup really well but not be too soft itself. Topped with some preserved veggies (mmm wish they put more), the stewed beef is nice and tender. The tendon is oh so soft ! (though sometimes I wish it was more "firm" so it has a nice bite to it).   We had recently came back from an LA trip where we had some really good cold salted duck wings. We had ordered the "Salted Duck" here to try. Their version wasn't wings, but more like the duck breast area w/ bone. Flavor overall was still decent but portion size was much smaller for the price.   Overall, yummy beef noodle soup. I inhale it every time. Only downside is Cash only up to like $15, then credit is allowed. If you are a solo diner, bring cash or order more XD

2kzv29OPeGqBoEtuyMRaUg.text: We ventured from the strip to Chinatown for lunch. We were glad we did. The six of us got a bowl of soup each and pork dumplings. The soup was 10/10. The dumplings were 7/10.   A ten minute cab drive from The Flamingo and you're there. There are many places to choose from, and we used Yelp to pick. We were very satisfied with our choice! Would recommend.

0BvOsk6xF15M7SyTJSSOEA.text: We come to Vegas every year and always overindulge in food.  One type of cuisine they gets a bit underrepresented for us in Vegas though is Chinese food because we've had such great Chinese food in Vancouver and HK, we never really fave Vegas Chinese food a chance.  At the recommendation of one of our fellow travellers we decided to check this place out.  We were pleasantly surprised...Some good quality Taiwanese beef noodle soup, fried pork chop noodle soup, and beef pancake roll. The noodles were cooked just right with a perfect amount of al dente and the soup base was rich and flavourful. And also, very reasonably priced! Pro tip: you're coming here for the food, so don't expect a super tidy environment or great service!

ckNMc77DKtj71xN5OzGROw.text: I was craving noodles and decided to check this place out. The Noodle Pot is a small sit down place in Asia town specializing in more Taiwanese style of dishes. (I'm still trying my best to identify differences between Dishes with Chinese influence.)  I ordered the beef and tendon stew noodle bowel. Also, I believe this was the most popular dish on the menu. (Note: Read the menu carefully and you'll notice the differences between the dishes that look similar.) When served, eat immediately in order enjoy the initial heat of the dish. Don't forget to eat the tendon. It's full of flavor and looks like a piece of fat if you are new to eating this type of dish. There's baby bok choy cabbage in there and some pickles as well to balance all the meat and noodle in the dish. I also try the mini dumplings. Spicy and tasty if you need a side dish.

VPHaHiVNTVB1V6J24uhnog.text: Great beef noodle soup - both clear and spicy broth were amazing. Beef roll was made with egg and not the thicker scallion pancake traditionally used which turned me a bit off - flavor good but texture off.  However, the beef noodle soup will hit the spot - not too salty and the beef was excellent. Coming back!

38Gnb1DkQMLRCWeWwedm6w.text: My newest obsession! I almost don't want to write a review because I want to keep this little spot all to myself. Though the tiny obscure sign helps disguise the restaurant quite well hehe. Look for the small "Noodle Pot" oval next to a looming sign in Chinese.   This restaurant tastes like...home. I always thought my mother didn't cook any specialty dishes (sorry for hating in the past, mom) but now I realize that everything she made for us was traditional Taiwanese style dishes! Which is exactly what this restaurant sells. You MUST go with the spicy beef noodle soup! The soup is hearty and rich in beef flavor. It is also heavier on the tomato side which some beef noodle soup enthusiasts might not be accustomed to, though it's exactly how my grandma makes it. The noodles they use are perfectly chewy, slightly wavy and neither too thin or thick and the beef chunks are tender and savory. It comes with plenty of baby bok choy and pickled mustard and cilantro.   For the side dishes I would recommend anything marinated! The cucumbers are garlicky, crunchy and refreshing while the cabbage is deliciously sour and spicy. My mouth is starting to water right now. Another must order is the beef wrap which is a thin green onion egg pancake wrapped around marinated beef slices, cilantro, and what seems like oyster sauce.  BUT THAT'S NOT ALL! You definitely need to order the chili oil wontons too. And all their dumplings are made in house. And finally the green bean (sweet mung bean, not the string variety) drink to top it all off! Noodle Pot is Taiwanese comfort food perfection.  P.S. More waitresses please. That is all.

ucf07OtsECZWYF7401loCQ.text: Any Taiwanese will tell you, a good bowl of beef noodle soup is hard to come by here in Vegas. So when I keep hearing about this place and finally decided to give it a try, I was not impressed.   Here is what we got:  1. Spicy Beef Noodle Soup with stew beef - it had good flavor but nothing special. our bowl came with some tendons though which was hard to chew.  2. Plain Beef Noodle Soup with flank - very plain taste with random vegetables (almost looked like a bowl of Pho)  3. Sauteed season veggies with garlic - overcooked boy choy, very soggy.  4. Beef Roll - this I will give them credit for, it was pretty tasty, I like the addition of peanuts and egg in here, not your average beef roll. But it was pretty greasy.  The service was friendly and not too busy on a Friday night. But would I come here again? Probably not. You can find better beef noodle somewhere else in my opinion.

n61kNfxByBVAo8yzI7VKPw.text: I've always enjoyed coming to noodle pot. I'm sad that their Henderson location was short lived but will gladly make the drive out to this one. The service is quick, I never find myself sitting down and waiting a long time to get my food. The cold appetizer dishes are some of my favorite - pig ears, pork feet, pickled cucumbers, beef and tripe, pressed tofu - they're all excellent. The wontons with spicy sauce are also good.  I could go on and on about the appetizers but the entrees are also good. Any of the beef noodle soups warm your soul. The fried pork chops are also excellent - even my picky kids will eat it. If you're not in the mood for noodles, they also have a beef stew you can get with rice.   They also have 3% off on Yelp :)

They put so much wonton in my soup I had to share it. I'm not complaining about that at all. You definitely get a good punt for your money.  Like most Asian restaurants do not expect good service. The time on yelp says they close at midnight but they really stop serving at 11:30. So be prepared if you come late, the girl working is going to give you an attitude. I asked her what time they close and she said we had until midnight to eat. That was fine but the attitude wasn't necessary. I watched a guy come running in trying to order and she flat out said no. Luckily, I don't come to restaurants like this expecting good service. It's all about the food for me, and that makes up for the girl with the bad attitude who wants to go home a half hour before they are supposed to close. Haha!

PLx3CysKN49z2eZJUliiVQ.text: This is gonna be an unusual review for me. While I did not love my first plate of authentic Taiwanese food, my experience tells me these plates are steeped in tradition-- and just because "I" may not enjoy a certain food, doesn't mean it deserves a lesser review.   I finished my plate. Full. Something organic and grounded to their plates; bone-in chicken, with a heavy serving of rice, and sides of pickled cabbage (which I loved). But the smoked-on fat which covered the chicken, and a musky smoked in flavor was just too much for me. But again, I can see why this plate (among others) would be a favorite to many, and no surprise why "A Bite of North America" awarded them a Certificate of Recognition.

PNS9qbC6xyLu-VxZ0gPBqg.text: So here is the deal, if you really want a hot bowl of fresh noodles, excellent bits of meat and fresh vegetables, all swimming in tasty broth - then this is the place to go.  You'll find it in Chinatown, in the mall, on the ground level, a little tucked away in a corner.  The night I went, it was a bit busy, but not packed (although we were asked to leave when we finished, as others were waiting).  The space is small, so large groups are going to have a hard time sitting and eating together.  My friend and I (who's lived in Vegas for four years), quickly found a seat and ordered right away.  We both got beef noodle soup and shared a place of pickled veggies.  What arrived was near perfection - hot bowl of broth with chewy sticky noodles and large chunks of beef sitting on top; oh and can't forget the green veggies!  Every bite was amazing, to the point you just slurp like a savage human and don't care what others think around you (because they're doing the same thing).  What else can I say, except that you'll get a hot bowl of beef noodle soup with complex flavors at a no bullsh*t price (*shrugs*).  Hit this place up, a short ride from the strip and under $30 for two peeps.

81Dc8bX-reF97EN_BBZ4iA.text: I absolutely love Noodle Pot! I came back twice within one month of my first time. Chinatown is kind of far for me, but I liked it that much and my boyfriend loved it too, even though I always just brought it home for him to try (to-go or leftovers). Some of their dishes are super delicious and authentic.  I would say the best things I've tried here are: -Beef Rolls- Its light and tasty, but eat it fresh! :)  -Clear Broth Beef Noodle Soup (make sure to get the one with chunks of beef vs. sliced beef) -Minced Pork over Rice- It was perfect and even had the pickled vegetables that I love so much  -Eggplant over rice (comes with fried egg) - Super flavorful and has meat bits in it  -THe spicy beef noodle soup was not spicy and lacked a savory taste. It's typically a soy sauce based soup, but it kind of tasted mostly like soy sauce. It wasn't bad, but the clear broth was significantly better.  -The pork over noodles was not MY personal cup of tea, but my boyfriend liked it. I added a large amount of the spicy sauce that they have on the table at the restaurant. (I also added that sauce to the eggplant over rice. It was good!) -The pork-cabbage dumplings were simply okay -The spicy wontons have a similar problem of too much soy sauce. Perhaps add some vinegar and some of the "spicy" sauce that they have on the table.   Parking can get crowded in this plaza around dinner time. They serve their hot tea in plastic cups, so try not to burn yourself. It's kind of a small restaurant so I don't recommend coming with especially large groups. Enjoy!

qf94EGhI1krnoq7AJuP1Sg.text: Place is good but not my favorite noodle restaurant in Vegas. This is a small Taiwanese noodle shop which is easy to miss with all the Asian restaurants pubs on Spring Mountain. I've been here twice before, first time I was very hungover second time I was not. Both times I ordered the spicy beef noodle soup. First time I was surprised about how flavorful the broth was. The beef was soft and noodles were chewy. The bowl exceeded my expectations. My second visit I came with high expectations but it didn't give me the same experience. Overall, very good noodle spot, especially if you tried all the other noodle restaurants in Vegas but it is not my favorite. I recommend a try.

MDyw7rH2zWLE5q1de0mSQg.text: Had the number two, beef noodle soup. It was definitely very flavorful. Price is reasonable. It does get pretty hot in the restaurant, especially in this weather, but the food makes it all up. Also had the spicy dumplings. It is not as easy as it sounds. I highly recommend the beef noodle soup though. The hot sauce is amazing. Will definitely come back!

hv0GUlHyqxIjabV3Gd8WYQ.text: What a perfect way to end our weekend trip in Vegas. I'm usually too lazy to leave the strip and end up getting a $20 bowl of pho at Noodle Asia in the Venetian but I'm so glad we made the trip out to this restaurant. Between 3 girls, we ordered the spicy taiwanese beef noodle soup, beef rolls, and the minced pork over rice. The noodle soup was amazing, probably one of the better ones I've had. The broth was very rich and flavorful, and had the perfect amount of spice. Their homemade chili oil is also super bomb, so don't forget to use that. Perfect cure for a hangover, would definitely recommend coming here!

a5lQvvAdljV8LcCl7IOKIQ.text: I would give zero stars if I could. I'm not sure why this place has so many good reviews. I ordered the chicken silk noodles to go. All I got was noodles, some peanut sauce on top that literally tasted like peanut butter, and some onions. Like... what? It was extremely cold on top of it, felt like they took it straight from the fridge, dumped plain noodles and one spoon of peanut butter on top and some random onions. Even trying to mix it was hard because all the noodles were clumped together with the thick sauce. I could not eat it, tasted so garbage, I actually scraped off the sauce to remake it in a pan at home. Had to season it like crazy and then it was somewhat edible. Never going back for sure.

Nda9nEVsQEmgRNHTpWMDbg.text: What a hidden gem among some great asian food options on Spring Mountain Road. I stopped here for lunch just after they open at 11 am and it was already packed! It's a tiny restaurant with just 8 tables, but of course good things come in small packages.  I had to try the beef noodle soup, which was awesome. Rich, slightly spicy beef broth with tender chunks of beef along with medium sized Chinese noodles. It was the perfect bowl of soup on a slightly chilly December morning. We also tried the pork dumplings. I was full from my soup, but couldn't stop eating the dumplings as they are the style I like...the wrapper dough is not too think and just the right balance of pork and cabbage.   I also liked the fact that they have a sign inside that said they were voted #13 best Chinese restaurant in the US by a restaurant ratings group (can't remember which one).  The staff here was very kind and friendly. Definitely a must try when looking for beef noodle soup in Vegas.

d6DEpYjaZKRyGj2YBuTl1g.text: Great, chewy noodles and very large portions. Ordered 3 dishes between two people and there was a lot of food that we couldn't finish. The bf is a very picky noodle eater, but he really enjoyed this restaurant and said it tastes like noodles in Taiwan. I just wasn't a fan of the beef roll. MZ4lTCRm4DvnIofTUodeFA.text: Prologue: One of the objectives for our recent trip to Las Vegas was to explore Chinatown more thoroughly then we had done in the past. We decided to give this place a try after reading some reviews and stopping by a few of the other restaurants in the vicinity.  The Plot: We began by sharing and order of Chives & Pork Dumplings, which was followed by two entrees, including a bowl of Beef Soup with Bean Thread Noodle and Simmered Pig Feet.  The Scene: The dumplings were steamed properly, the wrappers were firm yet still delicate, and the ground pork and broth inside were very tasty and nicely seasoned.  The consistency of the soup noodles and meat was spot on for us and the broth was just spicy enough.  The Rest of the Story: My fiancee, who is a native of mainland China, thought at the size of the dumplings was too small. I would have to agree, especially considering that this is a noodle house.  We also thought there was plenty of room in the soup bowl for a lot more noodles then we got.  The pigs feet, though very tasty, we're not fall off the bone tender and the flavor was not rich enough to satisfy my craving when ordering this dish.  The service was prompt in courteous. My fiancee thought the prices were a little high considering the portion sizes.  Epilogue: We will carry on with our exploration of Chinatown on our next visit to Las Vegas.  Photo Design By: Billie Z.

JtlR8aRUWz0nx6Sn-YGFLw.text: If your looking for beef and broccoli, orange chicken,or chow main..take your ass to Panda Express! Lol Noodle Pot does not serve any of that here. If your looking for more authentic foods and flavors of Chinese cuisine than this is your spot! Located in a  strip mall inside China town its a very small hole in the wall joint that does noodle dishes and soups right.   This place isn't fancy or beautiful but when I walked in there were a lot of customers eating and that's a good sign because I can almost guarantee most or half of them are repeat customers. But anyways we were immediately greeted by one of their employees and seated immediately. Once I saw the menu I knew this place isn't your commercial Chinese food spot. They stayed True to there roots which I respect!  We ordered then no less than 10 mins later we received our food.   Let me tell you the portion sizes of these dishes are insanely large lol ,and most of the items on the menu are less than 12 dollars. I'm pretty sure I didn't see one dish over 13 dollars lol. Now the way Chinese eat they like to share so you don't have to order individually they will provide you with small plates and bowls with out even asking them , I'm pretty sure they encourage it lol.   So we had 3 dishes . Dish 1 was their Beef &tendon noodle soup with spicy broth , the meat is so tender and juicy you can literally tear it apart with a spoon. The broth is super rich and the noodles are springy and hold the broth nicely. Definitely something I could eat everyday lol. Dish 2 was their popular beef rolls and man these things are huge lol. I loved them and the cucumber inside delivers a crisp fresh flavor, now it is a little too sweet for my liking however i would loved it if there were raw jalapeno slices but that's just my opinion. Dish 3 was the braised beef and noodle dry dish, this dish is basically an Asian take on spaghetti lol. It was super good very meaty with small tofu chucks , the sauce sticks to the noodles perfectly and tastes amazing.  I really want to give this place 5 stars but the location might be hard to find for some and the decor is lacking immensely. But other than that this place delivers a great home made feel and food. This is a True china town gem.I would  and will definitely be coming back. I do recommend GO GO GO!!

cRUYyWl7GFDcZ8GFXX7oPw.text: Best beef noodle in town. The chicken with rice is also delicious. The cold cucumber appetizer is yummy. I haven't tried a lot of things on their menu but everything I have tried was good. I make a trip here whenever I am in Vegas.

zM5y5Orn6vOhL_hDDzJhKg.text: Authentic Chinese ! So good I like the beef soup best. It can be challenging to find but once you do this little place never disappoints. I stick to the noodles as I haven't found too much love in my taste for their appetizers!

ZVg4CxBsIwM9SQ0e8WmP_w.text: Warm, comforting and delicious. That is how I feel about Noodle Pot.  My boyfriend was the one to turn me on to this little joint. We were looking for Chinese food originally, but he walked inside, just to take a peek. When he came back out, he was like, "Oh yeah. This looks good."  No doubt, he was spot on. I was a little bit skeptical at first, seeing that their mascot is some weird-looking pig, who is standing on his hind legs and holding a chicken drumstick in his hand. WEIRD. I giggled incessantly, but still decided to give it a chance.  Man, when the flavor of the soup broth hits you... Wow. It looks watery, but as soon as you sip a little bit (yes, just a teeny-tiny bit, because the soup is served the same temperature as the surface of the sun), it "whams" you in the mouth with a meaty punch.   I usually get the beef stew soup, but the man always gets either Beef and Tendon, or just the Tendon. I have been about four or five times now, and the consistency is always the same. Lots of tendon/beef, lots of flavor.   For all you Pho fans out there, it's a nice break from the norm, especially is you are looking for something a little hardier and meatier. This is gonna be an absolute staple place for me this coming winter.  PS- If you are lucky (like I was, one fateful evening), you might even run into the Duchess herself, Yuhi K. dining here!

4mMtn_Dncr8r4OpJ3NgdNw.text: Haven't had such tasteful noodles in a really long time. The beef noodle was extremely flavorful, maybe a tad too salty; But it was covered up by the spice! The spice might seem really intense but it was the right amount! The classic beef noodles costs $9 which is a little expensive but the taste makes up for it.   Be prepared for a wait to be seated!!! And it got so busy in the store where many people were standing around making the small dining area even smaller and I had conflicts with my neighboring table because of the confined space. Also, there were only two waitresses taking orders, serving food, and working the register... That was clearly not enough. I had to wait 5 minutes for a take out box!  But still, despite the wait and the cost, I had a really delicious bowl of Taiwanese beef noodles on this wintry day!

We had the spicy beef noodle soup and the wonton noodle soup. The broth for both weren't too salty and had a good bit of flavor to them. The wontons were smaller than what I'm used to, but everything in LA comes supersized already. The beef rolls were wrapped in some sort of thin flour mixed with egg and was quite delicious. Overall, the experience was great with their speedy service, polite waitresses, and otherwise brutally long waits in the buffet lines. I'd come here again if I ever encounter long buffet lines!

vHlUdoOO3ccVDoA7Qhfc_g.text: Many Las Vegans have declared that pursuing authentic Taiwanese food in this town is like finding a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow. My ever-growing curiosity in this uniquely ethnic cuisine, as well as guidance from people who are knowledgeable about this food has led me to Noodle Pot. I can say, without a shadow of doubt, that this establishment has superseded  my expectations!  Following a brief stop at the Shavery, I ran into Will (a.k.a. the artist formerly known as SnowFlake), along with a couple of Yelper's, and we decided to go to Noodle Pot. I have driven past this joint many times without thinking twice to stop in. It was a startling revelation to learn that, according to Will, Noodle Pot has some truly legitimate  Taiwanese grub in Vegas. Most notably, I wanted to try the national dish of Taiwan, spicy beef noodle soup.  I admire extraordinary mom-and-pop, hole-in-the-wall resto's, and Noodle Pot fits the bill to a tee. The comfortable yet lively vibe keeps the interaction going. After the server sat us down, we ordered some appetizers along with the spicy beef noodle soup.  Cold Vegetable Appetizer Plate - The first time I ordered this it came with pickled cucumbers and other vegetables, and wheat gluten. The cucumbers were marvelous, with the correct amount of saltiness to harmonize with the sweetness used in the sauce. The wheat gluten was another smash hit. It tasted incredibly akin to a concoction of beef and chicken.   (Note: Coming here on a separate visit, and ordering this dish again, they had replaced the wheat gluten with soy sauce hard-boiled eggs. I notably did not enjoy them, and I was not too confident to which tree the egg grows on, but that's just me ((hehe)).  Pork and Chive Dumplings - Another sublime feature! The dumpling wrappers tasted hand made, and the filling inside was outstanding with perfectly tender pork matching the bright flavor of the chives. The vinegary soy sauce dip was the icing on the cake.  Beef Roll - My least favorite item, but pretty splendid nonetheless. Slices of beef and cilantro wrapped around a thin crepe. I actually prefer other Chinese versions that use a thicker, flakier scallion pancake in which the inside is coated with hoisin sauce. But, it was delish.  Spicy Beef Noodle Soup - the "Piece de resistance" to our meal. We opted for the wide noodles instead of the regular noodles (think of it as thicker version of pappardelle). The noodles were perceived as if they were hand made and hand pulled, even though they probably came from a special noodle factory. The broth was nuts! It was packed with beef flavor, but exceptionally delicate. Hints of tomato added depth. Large portions of tender beef dotted the soup. Also, if the server has not brought out the chopped pickled cilantro, ask for it. That combined with the baby bok choy in the soup will give the dish a marvelous variation!  Many have mentioned this before, but I will proclaim it again. CASH ONLY!!! Save the plastic for the surgeon's table! :D  (Another side note: I took my brother here when he visited and at the time they had run out of beef so we opted for the Spicy Beef Tendon Soup. Even though I was fine, my brother returned home and had the hershey squirts for the next few days. The soup comes with a tremendous amount of tendons, so if you are not used to eating lots of offal or weird animal bits, I would be cautious when ordering this version).

U03xQUZroIs57fvEnPthhg.text: Stumbled upon Noodle Pot while walking through the Ranch 99 Chinatown plaza. It looked busy, I Yelped it and saw that it had gotten a decent reviews, so why not. Ordered a bowl of their signature beef noodle soup (in English on the menu overhead it all says "beef noodle soup" but they come with different things, like tendon, beef, etc.). We were seated right away as there was a table available, but while we were waiting for our food, a woman asked if someone was sitting there. We said no, and she plopped herself down while her hubby ordered food. We thought she just needed to get off her feet, but nope she was settling down and her husband sat right next to her. Okay, then.  Our beef noodle soup was okay, but they made it spicy at first and then said it only comes that way. I told her that the waitress said that they could make it non-spicy so then it took a while to come out. There are only about 10 tables in there, so don't expect to get seated right away if they're busy. We ordered the pork chop rice and when it came, I was like, "Where's the batter?" That's the first time in my life that I've ordered pork chop rice and it came like it was broiled. Weird. It tasted okay, but it's like going to KFC and ordering fried chicken and you come home and open the bucket and it's grilled chicken. Sucks.  It was about $8 each and you get plenty of food, but the noodles weren't the homemade kind I like and they weren't QQ enough. You know what I mean. Probably won't go back next time I'm in Vegas. I did like that they spoke Taiwanese and Mandarin though, and they were very nice there.

9jvctLCuA9KVpuz4CvqTlg.text: I stopped by here yesterday morning 10mins after they opened.  There was a total of 6 customers sitting towards the back SE wall already eating.  My family of 4 walked in, stood there for a few minutes and when the lady didn't move from behind the counter or respond back when we said hello we decided we'll just sit ourselves in front by the cooler/window. She finally came out and hard-highhandedly tossed the menus across the table causing the condiments at the other end to knock over.  We just assumed that it was an accident but she didn't say anything, look at us, or even offer napkins to clean the mess of chili oil on the table.  Waited over 10mins for her to take our order, and in this time she had helped/chatted/served a new group of 4 super quick.  I went to the counter and waited for her to approach the register so I can order.  When she did, it was when the 1st group of 6 came up to pay.  She blew me off and reached pass me to grab his money.  As soon as they got their change back, she went straight to a new group of 2 that just sat down.    I guess she couldn't see my 200lbs stature or no one informed her that when running a business GREEN is the only color that matters.

GquPDmTKeZO0IhgIfjwHgQ.text: Best place I've come across for Taiwanese beef noodle soup in Vegas thus far.   Always a good sign when I walk into a Chinese restaurant and they assume I'm a native speaker right off the bat so I'm happy to play the role of the fobby young immigrant looking for an oasis of good eats in the desert reminding him of the motherland (or mother island, depending on your politics).    My two times here I've gotten the spicy beef noodle soup and the pork feet noodle soup, both leaving me satisfied with warm soup belly and no residual sense of being parched from excessive MSG/salt.    The noodles offered come in two varieties: thin (nice Q-Q quality with an udon like consistency) and the thick hand-cut variety that are like nice al-dente dumpling strips).  The broth for the beef noodle soup has good balance in spice from the star anise/peppercorns with a lingering sweet finish and the beef is braised fork-tender (chopstick tender?) with plenty of marbled fatty goodness and accompanying tendon pieces that have been cooked down to the perfect chewy consistency.  If you're feeling a bit more adventurous and need to save a few extra bucks, the pork feet noodle soup is a bargain considering it is 2 dollars cheaper than the beef noodle soup and is loaded with large cartilaginous hunks of the soup's namesake that are braised so that everything falls off the bones with minimal effort.  The broth has a nice mild sweetness and the accompanying bok choy provides a nice contrast in crunch/color.  Probably not the best soup to order if you're on a date or if an attractive customer is sitting in front of you since this is one of those dishes you just need to go to town gnawing away and discarding the small bones aside every few bites, so just be comfortable in your own world of pork-liciousness.    Lots of other taiwanese classics and small cold plates at the counter, so definitely planning a return trip in the near future.  Cash only!

__811LyDMy2C_g3fFrfmEg.text: I love this place. The food is amazing and authentic. The service is the typical "Asian restaurant" service so don't expect anything above and beyond. The prices are good and the spicy tendon soup keeps me craving more and more! Love love this place.

sU04s_iucqwNL46UzS6qNQ.text: I regret not trying their beef noodle soup (main dish) because the dishes we ordered,  chicken leg with rice and noodle with meat sauce (Zha Jiang Mian) are definitely below average. Because of the lousy dishes we ordered, we are doubtful about going back for their beef noodle soup.

ZfEo7yYySMU7EKxl1B4ttw.text: Love this place! Great food great value. Spicy beef noodle is where it is at! (Napa dumplings were great too!) Noodles tasted so fresh. I wondered if they were homemade. Broth was perfect. Not too salty and just spicy enough!  Btw, the portion was so big for the spicy beef noodle that one bowl is enough for two. We made the mistake of ordering two noodle bowls and had to take the leftovers home which we did so gladly. I couldn't wait to eat the leftovers... And even soggy and day old it was still delicious! Being of Taiwanese decent I was so pleasantly surprised that this was a Taiwan style noodle shop. Almost all the customers spoke Mandarin which must mean that they serve good authentic Taiwanese food. I hope I can take my Taiwanese relatives here next time they visit Vegas. I can't wait to go back! Now on my favorites list of Vegas. =)

6FM0XDauYGFvz38Gh3FwrA.text: Perfect place for a casual quick meal.  Place reminds me of my mom's braised beef noodle stew but with homemade noodles.  The place is no frills except for free Wifi (Yay!), so not a place that you'd likely want to take a date to.  Otherwise service is acceptable, they're pretty quick to refill your water and get you anything.  Had to ask for extra napkins.  Located in the heart of Las Vegas Chinatown in the same place as Ranch 99.  The food was really good, so I'll probably go back.

I ordered the BEEF STEW SOUP, which was surprisingly not that bad. The noodles had a good texture, al dente! I like that the soup base is actually spicy, unlike some of the other soups I've had. Probably not as good as some of the noodle places I've had in the 626, but not too bad if you're in Vegas and you're craving some soup noodles.   Prices are decent, ~$8-9, after tax and tip.

Located in the same plaza as 99 Ranch market, Noodle Pot is a LIFESAVER for anyone craving Taiwanese comfort food.   Chilled cucumbers were a refreshing appetizer/side to beat the heat.   The spicy beef and tendon noodle soup was flavorful and had a nice kick to soothe my hangover from the night before. Would also be perfect when suffering from a cold or flu or allergies.   Wontons in chili oil were not spicy at all and a bit ugly to be honest but delicious nonetheless.   Boiled dumplings with shrimp beef and pork were not my fave. Will try the pork next time.

V9J38noNcDgIepaZEtcrpQ.text: This small mom-and-pop shop wins the award for good Taiwanese eats and solid beef noodle soup in LV.   Staff was exceptionally nice both times I ate here, but also keep in mind that Taiwan-style (and other Asian countries) is to let them know when you need something, not for them to come check on you.   Get the beef noodle soup with half tendon and half meat, just a little bit spicy. (I think it's #2.) Done well and finished with bok choy, cilantro, and a small bit of pickled vegetable. Only "problem" is that noodles come out exactly cooked and thereby end up slightly overdone by the time you reach the bottom of your bowl, but not sure how that's avoidable.   Seaweed and braised pork ear are both excellent here as well.   For those as bloody lost as I was while looking for this place, it's in the same complex as Volcano on the far right side, next door to the bakery. The English sign is SMALL!  Like all first generation Asian places, this place doesn't accept credit card unless you hit a min, which is $20 here. God forbid... Anyway, happy eating!

IeLDrUAhOsMiTt30LX4pMw.text: A hole in the wall, reasonably-priced Taiwanese restaurant in the Chinatown Plaza. Don't expect anything fancy; this spot is where locals flock to. Their spicy beef noodle soup and sliced stew beef noodle soup is really good! The beef was tender. Savory broth. I recommend the sliced stew beef noodle for anyone who doesn't like spicy food. The wonton noodle soup was underwhelming. Nothing special. Not flavorful. The noodles used for all three of these dishes were consistently good (thicker noodles cooked al dente). I heard this place uses MSG though. tldr; get the spicy beef noodle soup

HehY6PE2WsxtC3NjTuGREw.text: As someone who has been to Taiwan numerous times and has been captivated by the delightful taste of , or beef noodle soup, and someone who has been equally disappointed time after time trying to find a good beef noodle place shop in America, I can successfully say that I have found one place that has pretty authentic and delicious beef noodle soup.  Noodle Pot is located in Chinatown of Las Vegas, in a small shopping center, and is always busy with customers when I go. It seats about 40 people on the inside, so if you are going with a pretty big party (6+) at a peak time, I would say be prepared to wait a bit, but the food is definitely worth the wait.  Even when it is busy and I order the  (No. 1) on the menu and other people in my party order other dishes, the food never takes more than 10 or 15 minutes to come out. The store sells other Taiwanese side and main dishes that taste delicious as well, but none as good as the beef noodle soup.  The store has free wifi, and for all you Pokemon Go fans, is located close to three Pokestops as well. But don't just come for the free wifi, definitely try some soup as well!

Spicy wonton: 4 stars- chili sauce wonton with pork inside. Very good dish and not too spicy. Great flavors.  Minced pork noodle soup: 2 stars- let me explain the 2 stars. I was set on eating this dish which had tasty soup broth from the minced meat but for me it's all about the noodles. I had been to the other location in Henderson and the thick wide cut chewy noodles is what made the dish. Unfortunately they didn't have the wide chewy noodles so the dish was just not the same.   I've been to this location more than once and have not gotten the same sort of high quality I feel they have produced at their 2nd location.
